comments:
These articles need to be updated for Eclipse 3.1:
http://www.eclipse.org/articles/Article-RCP-1/tutorial1.html ,
http://www.eclipse.org/articles/Article-RCP-2/tutorial2.html ,
http://www.eclipse.org/articles/Article-RCP-3/tutorial3.html

Created an attachment (id=24895)
RCP Tutorial part 1 draft 1

Reassigning to me; interested parties please add yourself to the cc list.

Here's the first draft of the new tutorial, part 1. It was a bit more of a
rewrite than I first thought. I decided to go the full feature-product-native
launcher route that is the recommended best practice althought it made the
tutorial a little longer. Let me know what you think.

Like part 1, I plan for parts 2 and 3 to be similar to the scope of the current
parts but with a much heavier emphasis on using the PDE wizards and editors
than before.

Note that I plan to split up this bugzilla entry to just have one bugzilla per
part; I just think it will be easier to keep the attachments and comments
straight that way and it also lets me publish them on different schedules.
Split off part 2 into bug 104170, and part 3 into bug 104171.

I recommend to have a small "agenda" at the beginning of the first article (like
you may know from presentations). It should describe (very short) what the
reader will see in which part of the article series. That way the reader always
knows where he stands when he is following the tutorial and doesn't get this
feeling of being lost somewhere between blocks of instructions. :)

Hi Ed, I just read the revised article and I like it.

I have a few comments from a PDE perspective:

1. it would be better to focus on 3.1 and not dwell on the past, ie. what 
things were like pre-3.1.
Sentences like the ones below are an unnecessary distraction from the nice 
workflow you are describing.

"This (OSGi bundle format) is different from previous versions where it was 
recommended not to select this format." 

and 
"Trying out RCP applications used to be somewhat tedious. You had to create a 
custom launch configuration, enter the right application name, and tweak the 
plug-ins that were included."

2. "Unfortunately the Hello RCP template does not so we'll have to make one."
This was actually done intentionally, specifically for a case like yours (or 
the upcoming RCP book) when someone is trying to demonstrate the creation of a 
product from first principles.  We have richer templates for those who want 
them.

3. "You may see an error appear in the Problems view until you Synchronize 
(see below). This is normal. "

This problem fell through the cracks in 3.1.  Please tell people to first set 
the product name on the overview page and then press New... This way, they 
won't get the transient error marker and you wouldn't need to mention it.
We will fix this for 3.1.1 (i.e. if the product name is not set in the editor, 
we will add an extra field to the wizard) as this seems to be an unpleasant 
first impression to some.


4. "Typically this would not occur unless you are converting an older plug-in 
that did not use MANIFEST.MF into one that does"
This is not correct.  When you create a manifest.mf file for an existing plug-
in, PDE trims down the plugin.xml file to remove all redundant information, 
and only extensions/extension points are left in the xml file.

5. Very flattered that the troubleshooting section has become obsolete :-)

Nice piece of work overall.

Regarding comment #3, the parts are being written sequentially as I get time so
I don't have a table of contents for the other two parts yet.

Regarding comment #4, 1) I wanted some backward looking stuff to help someone
who read the previous version tell what was different. Maybe I overdid it. 2) It
would be better if the templates were more configurable so I could mix and match
what went into it, like a checkbox for a feature, a product, a view, branding,
etc.. 3) ok, 4) I was referring to a manual conversion, I'll make that clearer.

Thanks for the comments.

Created an attachment (id=24965)
RCP Tutorial part 1 draft 2

Updated, added source.
Part 1 has been published, closing.

thanks for the great tutorial (wanted to start with rcp since a while ago ;-)
a few things:
part 2 says " In part 1, we implemented one of the simpler methods, 
getInitialWindowPerspectiveId" -- but there's nothing in part 1 mentioning this, seems it 
belongs to the "Hello"-template?
there are several code snipptes but nothing about the files those snipptes fit into, a short info 
about the file's name would be very nice so a newbee like me knows which files to change ...

Parts 2 and 3 are in the process of being rewritten, see bug 104170 and bug
104171. Until that's done they're not going to match up, sorry.
Part 2 has been updated now.

Based on some feedback I've gotten on this article, I'm thinking of retooling it to get rid of the feature and making the example product plug-in based. The main reason is that it seems that hardly anybody uses just the plugins in the base rcp feature, and this has caused more than one person to stumble despite a note about that in the article. Anybody have any objections to this simplification?
Update for 3.1.2
A new version has been published of all three parts.

Minor, but confusing: 

"Now select the Configuration tab and click Add.... Select the plug-in you just created (org.eclipse.ui.tutorials.rcp.part1) and then click on Add Required Plug-ins." 

Should specify that the coder should "Open the launch configuration for the product" (otherwise it's opaque which "Configuration" tab is being discussed.)

At that point you're still in the Product Configuration editor, and don't need to open the launch configuration. You select the Overview tab and do something, select the Configuration tab and do something, then select the Overview tab again and do something. So unless I'm missing something (which is possible!) I think it's correct the way it's written.

(In reply to comment #15)
> At that point you're still in the Product Configuration editor, and don't need
> to open the launch configuration. You select the Overview tab and do something,
> select the Configuration tab and do something, then select the Overview tab
> again and do something. So unless I'm missing something (which is possible!) I
> think it's correct the way it's written.
> 
I see the problem, now -- the issue I was addressing is that the new plugin does *also* need to be added in the "Plugins" tab of the launch-config wizard -- a step I often forget, and which I was looking to see mentioned in the article.

I've tried running part 1 in latest 3.2 build and found that exporting the project to \deploy folder exports the plugin only, but not the eclipse executable or core libraries- is this the expected behaviour?
Andreas, you probably exported the plug-in instead of the product. If you export the product it should give you the executable and everything else.

(In reply to comment #12)
> Update for 3.1.2

Does this mean the projects in the 'accompanying zip files' will not work with 3.1.1 any more? 

When launching after exporting as described I get:
...
org.osgi.framework.BundleException: The activator org.eclipse.ui.tutorials.rcp.part1.Part1Plugin for bundle org.eclipse.ui.tutorials.rcp.part1 is invalid
...
org.eclipse.core.runtime.CoreException[1]: java.lang.ClassNotFoundException: org.eclipse.ui.tutorials.rcp.part1.Application
...

(In reply to comment #19)
OK after deleting...unzipping...importing...not changing anything...exporting again.

If you change anything, like the name of your application or the name of your plug-in or the name of your main class, it's hard to find all the places that need to be changed. I've often had this problem when copying projects. This is better in 3.2 but I don't think it's completely automatic yet.

I am following part 1 of the tutorial: http://www.eclipse.org/articles/Article-RCP-1/tutorial1.html

I am using Eclipse 3.2 (from the Callisto release).

Comment about the section "Making it a product": There is something missing in the description here. When I follow the steps in the tutorial and try to launch my application from the product config file, I get an error that indicates that the splash screen cannot be found.

Found some more info about this in the bug database: bug #66421

I found the solution in comment #24 of that bug: "Ricky, your product configuration is missing the required bundles.  On the configuration tab of your product definition you must click the "Add Required Plug-ins" button to add the necessary bundles to launch."

The tutorial should mention this.
Thanks for the tip Jesper.

Any idea?
Thanks in advance!

I've found that some part of the name produces the issue, but I don't know why, I'm an eclipse newbie.

Any other, of bigger lenght works.
I guess it is the "org.eclipse.ui" part.

I am eager to start understanding Eclipse, so I hope an explanation to this issue will come.

Thanks in advance.
Mike

The "Missing required bundle org.eclipse.ui_0.0.0." error is the main clue, I think. Either there's something wrong with your config.ini (probably in the osgi.bundles line), or maybe you're not supplying all the bundles that are required when you deploy the app (or don't have them selected in the plug-ins tab of the launch configuration).

(In reply to comment #27)
> The "Missing required bundle org.eclipse.ui_0.0.0." error is the main clue, I
> think. Either there's something wrong with your config.ini (probably in the
> osgi.bundles line), or maybe you're not supplying all the bundles that are
> required when you deploy the app (or don't have them selected in the plug-ins
> tab of the launch configuration).
> 

No, the containment of "org.eclipse.ui" in the name of the plugin generates this error.
If I name it "org.eclipse.gui.xxxx", it works fine. I think there's an issue related to an asumption of the Eclipse framework somewhere based on the "org.eclipse.ui" part of the name in Eclipse 3.2.x.

Hi, I'm back to tell you that something strange is happening, indeed. If you saw my previous comment, that problem is happening ONLY in Eclipse 3.2.1 (I have M20060921-0945)! In 3.1.1 (M20050929-0840) there is no problem at all.

More than that, in 3.2.1, the plug-ins that were supposed to be exported as .jar's (as the tutorial says), are actually exported as folders, under "RcpTutorial1/plugins".

Is this strange or what? Can anyone enlighten me, please?

Hi, it's me again. I also made it in Eclipse 3.3.0 (I20061214-1445) and it's working. At this point, maybe it's just the version 3.2.* which has a problem?

Can anyone confirm or infirm this?

Florin, as far as I know you're the only one who has run into this problem. I certainly never saw it in various versions of 3.1, 3.2, or 3.3, though I can't say for sure that I tried it in the exact same versions you tried it in. If it were some kind of generic bug I'd expect to see a lot of people complain about it, but since that's not the case I'd suspect something unique in your setup.

It's easy (I've done it several times myself) to get something messed up in the plug-in dependencies or target environment that could give errors like this, especially when migrating from one version of Eclipse to another. Other common problem sources are problems unpacking the zip, unpacking one version of Eclipse on top of another, and I've even seen a corrupt download or two.

(In reply to comment #32)
First of all, thanks for answering.

I don't know what to say/think, it's just what happened to me. I used different Eclipse installations (not unpacking on top of each other). I still have them installed (each of them also contains other working projects). Every time I followed the tutorial's steps and only on one version it didn't work. Maybe it's just something strange (since nobody else stumbled at the same point).

Anyway, I'm happy I have at least to versions that are working, so I got the picture of Eclipse's RCP mechanism and went on. Thanks.
